variable description: Basin mean of snow percent of total precipitation estimate, mean for period 1901-2000.
source var description: Catchment snow percent of total precipitation estimate, mean for period 1901-2000.

variable description: Basin average of mean day of the year of first freeze, derived from 30 years of record (1961-1990), 2km PRISM. For example, value of 300 is the 300th day of the year (Oct 27th).
source var description: Catchment mean day of the year of first freeze

variable description: Basin average of mean day of the year of last freeze, derived from 30 years of record (1961-1990), 2km PRISM.  For example, value of 100 is the 100th day of the year (April 10th).
source var description: Catchment mean day of the year of last freeze

variable description: Subsurface flow contact time index. The subsurface contact time index estimates the number of days that infiltrated water resides in the saturated subsurface zone of the basin before discharging into the stream.
source var description: Catchment contact time index

variable description: Base Flow Index (BFI), The BFI is a ratio of base flow to total streamflow, expressed as a percentage and ranging from 0 to 100. Base flow is the sustained, slowly varying component of streamflow, usually attributed to ground-water discharge to a stream.
source var description: Catchment BFI

variable description: Topographic wetness index, ln(a/S); where "ln" is the natural log, "a" is the upslope area per unit contour length and "S" is the slope at that point.  See http://ks.water.usgs.gov/Kansas/pubs/reports/wrir.99-4242.html and Wolock and McCabe, 1995 for more detail
source var description: Catchment topwet index

variable description: Dunne overland flow, also know as saturation overland flow, is generated in a basin when the water table "outcrops" on the land surface (due to the infiltration and redistribution of soil moisture within the basin), thereby producing temporary saturated areas. These saturated areas generate Dunne overland flow through exfiltration of shallow ground water and by routing precipitation directly to the stream network.
Rainfall and Runoff factor ("R factor" of Universal Soil Loss Equation); average annual value for period 1971-2000
source var description: Catchment R factor

variable description: Horton overland flow, also known as infiltration-excess overland flow, is generated in a basin when infiltration rates are exceeded by precipitation rates.
Estimated basin mean depth to water table in meters
source var description: Estimated catchment mean depth to water table in meters

variable description: Average value of silt content in basin (percentage)
source var description: Silt content in catchment (percentage)

variable description: Average value of clay content in basin (percentage)
source var description: Clay content in catchment (percentage)

variable description: Average value of sand content in basin (percentage)
source var description: Sand content in catchment (percentage)

variable description: Percentage of soils in hydrologic group A. Hydrologic group A soils have high infiltration rates. Soils are deep and well drained and, typically, have high sand and gravel content.
source var description: Catchment value (percentage)

variable description: Percentage of soils in hydrologic group A/C. Hydrologic group A/C soils have group A characteristics (high infiltration rates) when artificially drained and have group C characteristics (slow infiltration rates) when not drained.
source var description: Catchment value (percentage)

variable description: Percentage of soils in hydrologic group A/D. Hydrologic group A/D soils have group A characteristics (high infiltration rates) when artificially drained and have group D characteristics (very slow infiltration rates) when not drained.
source var description: Catchment value (percentage)

variable description: Percentage of soils in hydrologic group B. Hydrologic group B soils have moderate infiltration rates. Soils are moderately deep, moderately well drained, and moderately coarse in texture.
source var description: Catchment value (percentage)

variable description: Percentage of soils in hydrologic group B/C. Hydrologic group B/C soils have group B characteristics (moderate infiltration rates) when artificially drained and have group C characteristics (slow infiltration rates) when not drained.
source var description: Catchment value (percentage)

variable description: Percentage of soils in hydrologic group B/D. Hydrologic group B/D soils have group B characteristics (moderate infiltration rates) when artificially drained and have group D characteristics (very slow infiltration rates) when not drained.
source var description: Catchment value (percentage)

variable description: Percentage of soils in hydrologic group C. Hydrologic group C soils have slow soil inflitration rates. The soil profiles include layers impeding downward movement of water and, typically, have moderately fine or fine texture.
source var description: Catchment value (percentage)

variable description: Percentage of soils in hydrologic group C/D. Hydrologic group C/D soils have group C characteristics (slow infiltration rates) when artificially drained and have group D characteristics (very slow infiltration rates) when not drained.
source var description: Catchment value (percentage)

variable description: Percentage of soils in hydrologic group D. Hydrologic group D soils have very slow infiltration rates. Soils are clayey, have a high water table, or have a shallow impervious layer.
source var description: Catchment value (percentage)

variable description: Percentage of soils in hydrologic group VAR. Hydrologic group VAR soils have variable drainage characteristics.
source var description: Catchment value (percentage)

variable description: Average K-factor value for the uppermost soil horizon in each soil component. K-factor is an erodibility factor which quantifies the susceptibility of soil particles to detachment and movement by water. The K-factor is used in the Universal Soil Loss Equation (USLE) to estimate soil loss by water. Higher values of K-factor indicate greater potential for erosion
source var description: Catchment value (percentage)

variable description: Average value of percent by weight of soil material less than 3 inches in size and passing a No. 10 sieve (2 mm)
Average value of percent by weight of soil material less than 3 inches in size and passing a No. 200 sieve (.074 mm)
Average value of percent by weight of soil material less than 3 inches in size and passing a No. 4 sieve (5 mm)
Average value of organic matter content (percent by weight)
Average permeability (inches/hour)
Average value of total soil thickness examined (inches)
Average value of bulk density (grams per cubic centimeter)
Average value for the range of available water capacity for the soil layer or horizon (inches of water per inches of soil depth)
Average value of depth to seasonally high water table (feet)
Percent of watershed composed of geology class according to Reed & Bush (2001).
Percent of watershed composed of geology class according to Reed & Bush (2001).
Percent of watershed composed of geology class according to Reed & Bush (2001).
Percent of watershed composed of geology class according to Reed & Bush (2001).

Percent of watershed composed of geology class according to Reed & Bush (2001).
Percent of watershed composed of surficial geology (Hunt 1979): Sea islands
Coral
Backshore deposits
Pre-Wisconsinan drift
Till, or ground moraine
Ice-laid deposits, like tg but mostly sand and silt
Thin ice-laid deposits, like ts but thin and discontinuous.  Extensive exposure of underlying Cretaceous- and Tertiary-age formations
Deposits of mountain glaciers
Gravel, sand and clay deposited by glacial streams adjacent to   or downstream from temporary ice fronts
Floodplain and alluvium gravel terraces
Fan gravels
Fan sands
Pliocene-age and older stream deposits on the Great Plains
Lake deposits
Sand sheets, mostly with dunes or sand mounds at surface
Sand sheets on sandy and gravelly Ogallala Formation in southern Great Plains
Wisconsinan loess
Deeply weathered loess
Basalt
Bedrock
Micaceous residuum without much quartz; clay,  mostly kaolinite
Residuum with abundant quartz; much less mica than rsh, but equal to clay
Clay residuum with little mica or quartz; mostly massive kaolinitic clay
Red clay, massive clay that is generally kaolinitic
Cherty red clay; similar to rls, but with chert from the parent rock
Residuum on Triassic-age formations; depths less than most other saprolite, reddish color, largely inherited from from parent rock
Sandy residuum, derived by intensive weathering of sandstone formations. Sand locally is in dunes
Clay residuum that swells when wet; developed by weathering  of poorly consolidated shale, containing the clay mineral montmorillonite, generally less than 10 feet
Loam; texture variable, ranging from sand to clay, mostly  non-swelling clay mineral, kaolinite; otherwise similar to rc
Intensively weathered upper Tertiary- and Quaternary-age gravels; thickness generally less than 30 feet,  distribution not completely known
Phosphatic clay; poorly sorted clay and phosphate pebbles or nodules in sandy matrix. Thickness 10 to 50 feet, commonly overlain by loose sand. Major source of phosphate fertilizer
Sandy or silty residuum; probably includes loess. Depth generally less than 10 feet
Silt on limestone; probably includes considerable loess; extensive bare rock
Sandy ground; mostly on poorly consolidated sandstone  formations
Shaley or sandy ground; on mixed sandstone and shale formations; where shaley, contains considerable swelling clay
Sandy gypsiferous ground; many sinks, local dunes; vegetation scanty or lacking where there is much gypsum or other salt
Clayey ground on weathered Permian- and/or Triassic-age red beds
Marshes, swamps, peat deposits; only locally thicker than 12 feet
Sandy coastal ground with organic layer over a shallow water  table, ground water podsols
Sandy and stony colluvium derived mostly from sandstone and shale
Stony colluvium on limestone; considerable admixed silt,  possibly of loess origin
Stony colluvium on metamorphic rocks; less silt and clay than in co/ls
Colluvium on volcanic rocks
Bouldery and sandy colluvium on granitic rocks
Clayey and loamy colluvium; on poorly consolidated rocks on  lee sides of Pacific Coast Ranges

Mean watershed percent Calcium Oxide concentration of lithology (percent).
Mean watershed percent Iron Oxide concentration of lithology (percent).
Mean watershed percent Magnesium Oxide concentration of lithology (percent).
Mean watershed percent Phosphorus concentration of lithology (percent).

Mean watershed percent Silica Oxide concentration of lithology (percent).
Mean watershed Rock Uniaxial Compressive Strength, megaPascals.
Mean watershed rock hydraulic conductivity (x10^6 meters / second).
Mean watershed annual natural groundwater recharge,days.

based on polyline coverage of average annual runoff in the conterminous
United States, 1951-1980 (in), Gebert, W.A., Graczyk, D.J., and Krug, W.R. 1987
Watershed mean index of aridity, computed as the difference between mean annual ET and mean annual precipitation.
